quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 9 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 9.9: Electrolysis
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Electrolytic cells, molten salts, and aqueous solutions

questions.question: Which of the following is a key difference between a galvanic cell and an electrolytic cell?
options: An electrolytic cell requires an external power source to drive a non-spontaneous reaction.
Oxidation occurs at the cathode in an electrolytic cell.
An electrolytic cell produces electrical energy from chemical reactions.
Electrolytic cells do not require an electrolyte.
questions.explanation: Galvanic cells produce energy from spontaneous reactions, whereas electrolytic cells consume energy to force non-spontaneous reactions to occur.

questions.question: In an electrolytic cell, the anode is assigned which charge?
questions.explanation: Because the external power source 'pulls' electrons from the anode, it is the positive electrode in an electrolytic cell (though oxidation still occurs there).

questions.question: What are the products of the electrolysis of molten sodium chloride ($NaCl$)?
questions.explanation: In a molten salt (no water), the only available ions are $Na^{+}$ (reduced to $Na$ at the cathode) and $Cl^{-}$ (oxidized to $Cl_{2}$ at the anode).

questions.question: During the electrolysis of aqueous $Na_{2}SO_{4}$, why is hydrogen gas produced at the cathode instead of sodium metal?
options: Water is more easily reduced than $Na^{+}$ ions.
Sodium ions are too heavy to move to the cathode.
The sulfate ions prevent sodium from reacting.
Sodium metal is a gas at room temperature.
questions.explanation: The reduction potential of water is less negative than that of $Na^{+}$, so water is reduced to $H_{2}$ gas preferentially in aqueous solutions.

questions.question: In the process of electroplating a silver spoon with gold, where should the spoon be placed?
questions.explanation: The object to be plated must be the cathode so that metal ions ($Au^{3+}$) in the solution are reduced and deposited onto its surface.

questions.question: What gas is produced at the anode during the electrolysis of dilute sulfuric acid ($H_{2}SO_{4}$)?
questions.explanation: In dilute acidic solutions, water is oxidized at the anode to produce oxygen gas and $H^{+}$ ions.

questions.question: Which of the following is an industrial application of electrolysis?
options: The production of Aluminum from Bauxite (Hall-HÃ©roult process).
The combustion of gasoline in an engine.
The fermentation of sugar into alcohol.
The neutralization of an acid with a base.
questions.explanation: Aluminum is highly reactive and cannot be reduced by carbon; it must be extracted via the electrolysis of molten cryolite and alumina.

questions.question: In the electrolytic refining of copper, the pure copper deposits on:
options: The bottom of the tank as sludge
questions.explanation: Impure copper is oxidized at the anode, and pure $Cu^{2+}$ ions travel through the solution to be reduced back to solid metal at the cathode.

questions.question: What is the standard cell potential ($E^{\circ}_{cell}$) for an electrolytic process?
questions.explanation: A negative $E^{\circ}_{cell}$ indicates that the reaction is non-spontaneous and requires an external voltage at least equal to the cell potential to proceed.

questions.question: When electrolyzing aqueous $KI$, a brown color appears near the anode. This is due to the formation of:
questions.explanation: Iodide ions ($I^{-}$) are oxidized at the anode to form molecular iodine ($I_{2}$), which appears brown in solution.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the principles of electrolysis.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You understand the competition between water and ions.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review the signs of electrodes in electrolytic cells.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the difference between molten and aqueous electrolysis.
